awd_titl_txt: Molecular Structures of Interfacial Proteins Studied by Isotope Labeling and Sum Frequency Generation Vibrational Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Zhan Chen and his group at the University of Michigan are developing an innovative approach to elucidate detailed molecular structures of surface-bound proteins.  Their approach uses selective heavy-atom (isotope) labeling and advanced spectroscopic methods to derive crucial knowledge about how adsorption of proteins at interfaces affects their structure and function.  These interactions impact a range of applications, such as biocompatibility of biomedical materials, performance of antifouling coatings, selectivity and sensitivity of biosensors, and efficiency of biofuel cells. This highly interdisciplinary research provides educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students.  Professor Chen and his students are also working to engage high school students (including those from underrepresented groups, including women) and to enhance their interest in science through a class taught each summer. 

This project focuses on the development of a generally applicable methodology to characterize the conformation and orientation of proteins at interfaces using isotope labeling and sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy. Using a model cell membrane-associated antimicrobial peptide tachyplesin I, a protein GB1 mutant which can retain its native structure at the graphene interface, and a wild-type protein GB1 which denatures on graphene, Professor Chen and his group are developing SFG isotope labeling methods to characterize various protein secondary structures at the solid/liquid interface; to deduce orientations and slight conformation changes of interfacial proteins from crystal structures due to interfacial interactions; and to determine conformations of denatured interfacial proteins. Results obtained from molecular dynamics simulations and the Hamiltonian approach are compared to the experimentally measured SFG data from isotopically labeled proteins to determine the most likely protein conformations and orientations at the interface. This method can also be used to determine interfacial structures of proteins with unknown crystal structures, adding a powerful spectroscopic tool for studying interfacial biological molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this research, we successfully developed a systematic methodology to deduce molecular structures of peptides and proteins in situ at solid/liquid interfaces in real time. This method combined the applications of sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy, molecular dynamics (MD) simulation, Hamiltonian SFG spectra calculation and spectra matching, and isotope labeling. This method is generally applicable to determine conformations and orientations of interfacial peptides and proteins. MD simulations provide potential peptide/protein conformations as inputs for Hamiltonian calculation, while the introduction of isotope-labeled amino acids in peptides and proteins greatly increases the independently measured SFG structural parameters, leading to the feasibility of determining molecular structures of interfacial peptides and proteins. This research added a powerful spectroscopic means to the toolbox for studying biological molecules, which can greatly impact the research fields of nonlinear optical spectroscopy and biological interfaces, providing further understanding on biological molecule interactions at interfaces.

The developed methodology has been applied to study molecular structures of protein GB1 on polystyrene (PS) and amine terminated self-assembled monolayer (SAM). A wild-type protein GB1 and a mutant protein GB1 were included in this investigation. Both nonlabelled and isotope-labeled proteins were studied. It was found that due to the strong pi-pi interaction between the amino acids on the helix of the wild-type protein GB1 and the surface phenyl groups on the PS surface, the helical structure in protein GB1 contacts the PS surface and lies down. For the mutant protein GB1, with two amino acids in the helix which could participate in pi-pi interactions being mutated with alanine, the pi-pi interaction between mutant GB1 and the PS surface greatly decreased, leading to a standing-up pose for the helix in the protein on the PS surface. This study indicates that by only mutating two key amino acids, we could greatly change the protein interfacial structure. On the amine terminated SAM surface, due to the lack of interfacial pi-pi interactions, the wild-type and mutant protein GB1 molecules adopt a similar orientation, with the helix standing up on the surface. The developed method was also used to examine the structures of tachyplesin I associated with a lipid bilayer to model the bacterial cell membrane. It was found that the SFG spectra calculated with aggregated tachyplesin I could better match the experimental data than a single tachyplesin I peptide, indicating that likely tachyplesin I molecules aggregated while interacting with bacterial cell membrane to kill bacteria. Tachyplesin I is a widely studied antimicrobial peptide. The in-depth understanding of antimicrobial peptide-bacterial cell membrane interactions will aid in the design and development of antimicrobial peptides with improved performance to overcome bacterial drug resistance.

Interfacial peptide and protein structures, such as orientations and conformations, determine many properties of bio-interfaces, such as biocompatibility of biomedical materials, performance of antifouling coatings, sensitivity and selectivity of biosensors using antibodies and enzymes, efficiency of biofuel cells, productivity of oil-water separation, membrane protein functions, and activities of antimicrobial peptides, etc. Therefore, the elucidation of interfacial peptide and protein structures using the developed methodology in this research can greatly facilitate in-depth understanding on structure-function relationships of peptides and proteins at interfaces. With such understanding, through structural optimization of interfacial peptides and proteins and/or optimized interfacial interactions, the performance of biomaterials, marine antifouling coatings, antimicrobial peptides, drugs targeting membrane proteins, biosensors, antibody drugs, and the efficiency of oil-water separation can be improved. The use of such improved materials and drugs will have a positive impact on everyday life, beyond scientific research.

Education and research have been integrated in this project. This highly interdisciplinary project provides vigorous training opportunities for young researchers who are directly involved in this research in many areas in chemistry, biology, and engineering, preparing them for future employment in related fields. Other students and postdocs (including minority and women researchers) in the PI's and the collaborators' groups are educated through group meetings, discussions, and interactions with the students who are directly working on the project. The PI integrated related contents in his lectures for graduate and undergraduate courses, as well as a summer surface science class for high school students to promote students' interests in chemistry and in science in general, to prepare them for their future studies and employment. The dissemination of the knowledge obtained from this research through publications and presentations also educates researchers in the related fields all over the world.
